payload.title: Entry Requirements
payload.description: Thailand has streamlined entry for most tourists. Ensure your passport is in good condition.
notes: Apply for an e-Visa online if your stay exceeds 30 days.
Passport must be valid for 6 months from your date of entry.

payload.title: Getting Around the City
payload.description: Beat the famous Bangkok traffic by using the elevated Skytrain (BTS) or the underground MRT.
notes: The Airport Rail Link is the fastest way to avoid highway gridlock.
Use Chao Phraya Express boats for a scenic route to the Grand Palace.

payload.title: Payments & Tipping
payload.description: While cards are great for malls, Bangkok is still a city fueled by street food and cash.
notes: Small change is vital for street vendors and 'Tuk-Tuks'.
Tipping isn't strictly expected, but rounding up the bill is common.

payload.title: Staying Safe
payload.description: Bangkok is very safe for solo travelers, though petty scams exist near major temples.
notes: Always ask taxi drivers to turn on the 'Meter'.
Ignore anyone claiming the Grand Palace is 'closed for a holiday'—it's likely a scam.
Perfect walking weather, but expect crowds and higher hotel prices.
Extremely high humidity. Songkran festival in April is a highlight.
Short, heavy bursts of rain. Great for luxury hotel deals.

payload.name: The Grand Palace
payload.description: The former royal residence and home to the Emerald Buddha.

payload.name: Wat Arun
payload.description: The 'Temple of Dawn' on the west bank of the river.
